content.raw: Note that constraining to the x, y, and z axis when rotating has not been added.  The primary reasons were that there is no significant advantage gained from this functionality as well as the functionality being managed by the `TransformController` which will highlight an axis upon it being activated.  In order for the rotation math to work out correctly, the axis must be activated so the behavior might confuse the user when they select the z axis, hold down `x` and see that the x axis is now highlighted even though their mouse hasn’t moved.  If one wants to rotate along a specific axis, they can simply click the desired axis or hold Shift to rotate according to the world frame.
content.html: Note that constraining to the x, y, and z axis when rotating has not been added. The primary reasons were that there is no significant advantage gained from this functionality as well as the functionality being managed by the TransformController which will highlight an axis upon it being activated. In order for the rotation math to work out correctly, the axis must be activated so the behavior might confuse the user when they select the z axis, hold down x and see that the x axis is now highlighted even though their mouse hasn’t moved. If one wants to rotate along a specific axis, they can simply click the desired axis or hold Shift to rotate according to the world frame.

nice works well for me!

One behavior I noticed that’s different from gazebo is when constraining the x, y, z axis. In gazebo, after translating in z axis \(or any other axis\), I can press x and continue to translate in the x direction while the object keeps its z position. Here in ignition, z resets when I tries to move in x.

content.raw:
Thanks for catching this, it was a tricky bug and at first seemed like a trivial problem but actually was pretty important to fix. Everything ~should~ be good now…

The case was when the mouse was released while the translating hotkeys are still being held. I was making the assumption that one should release the hotkeys first and then release the mouse, so doing it the other way around put the system into a state it shouldn’t have been in.
content.html:
Thanks for catching this, it was a tricky bug and at first seemed like a trivial problem but actually was pretty important to fix. Everything ~should~ be good now…

The case was when the mouse was released while the translating hotkeys are still being held. I was making the assumption that one should release the hotkeys first and then release the mouse, so doing it the other way around put the system into a state it shouldn’t have been in.

content.raw: Do we need to `Start` both on press and release? Also I think we shouldn't be setting the press pos on a release, right?
content.html: Do we need to Start both on press and release? Also I think we shouldn't be setting the press pos on a release, right?

content.raw: The press position needs to be set on a translation button press or release as well as a mouse click press.  This is so that the motion of dragging an object stays consistent and isn’t jumpy. `Start` is needed on both a button press and release due to the `Start` function updating the start pose and scale of the node currently being operated.  If the `Start` is not in the release button code, the object will teleport back to where it began on a button press.
content.html: The press position needs to be set on a translation button press or release as well as a mouse click press. This is so that the motion of dragging an object stays consistent and isn’t jumpy. Start is needed on both a button press and release due to the Start function updating the start pose and scale of the node currently being operated. If the Start is not in the release button code, the object will teleport back to where it began on a button press.
